text: “Oh my God.”

On March 13, Russian warplanes
bombed a base

in Western Ukraine that
since the start of the war

had been used to arm and train
hundreds of foreign fighters
to deploy to the front lines.

Just days before, we met
some of those fighters

as they arrived
in Ukraine

and spoke with them
about their motivations
to fight against Russia.

“If I have to fight,
I will fight.”
“I’m scared for Ukraine.”

In Lviv, we met a volunteer
coordinator who goes by Doc.

He was helping fresh arrivals
get set up with a meal

and lodging and then
registered to get a weapon.

Doc isn’t working in
an official capacity,

but he’s seizing the moment
to serve his country.

“I started to coordinate
this process

since the time when
Putin bombed in Kiev.
Practically next day.
Check.

Go to local territorial
defense office.

I understood that I should
do something useful
for all country,

invite my friends
from abroad,

and organize some
logistics here

for getting volunteers
to help us.”

After Russia’s invasion,
Ukraine’s president called

on foreigners to join 
a newly formed

international defense legion 
to bolster the country’s army.
He hailed them all as heroes.

And thousands of people
from around the world
have been answering that call.

Some are joining
Ukraine’s armed forces.

Others are trying to get
to the battle on their own.
“O.K., let’s go.”
“What is the base?”

“It’s secret.
It’s top secret, please.”
“Ah, O.K. O.K.”

“I’ve been in Middle East
before, fighting ISIS

for three years with the
Kurdish militia and army.

When this happened,
I felt the same reasons

that I once felt
to go down to fight

the terrorist organization,
ISIS.

People were suffering
and people were dying
for no reason —

like, no respect for the
civilians, for the children,
for anybody.

I cannot change the world,
but I can be a part of helping

in the defending
of the world.”

Walking the streets,
the volunteers were approached

by more foreigners
looking to help.

Adam here came from
Southern California.
“So you’re American.
What is your name?”
“I’m American and Israel.”
“Israel.”
“Adam.”
“Adam, let’s go with us.”
“Yes.

They are from Sweden,
Italy and Finland.”

“It's my third stop
at an enlistment office.

They keep transferring me
from place to place

because I can’t find one
for foreigners.
It’s only for the locals.”
“Yeah.”
“So —”

Eager to get to the fight,
Jasper, Ricardo and Pedro
decided to leave Doc

and were recruited to join
the official army.

They headed off
to the training base
that was later attacked.

Meanwhile, Doc took in
new volunteers —

two Americans
and a Spaniard.
“Professional go to army,

not real skilled guys go to
humanitarian branch ...”

“Flew to New York,
then to Poland from there.

Then we just took a FlixBus
across the border.

And then after that,
we just came to Lviv.
We’re staying here for a bit,

and then I met up
with those guys.

And now we’re on our way
to the military office
to get signed up.

I did something similar
when I was 19.

I went to Iraq to join up
with the YBS.

So it’s not like my first time
traveling overseas

and going to a
dangerous area.

That’s after we organize
all our ammunition and stuff.

We had a couple of
old Russian grenades

in the back too when
we were over there.

I worked at a place
called Taco Bell.

It’s a fast food restaurant
in the U.S.

It’s really easy for me
to save up money,

and I saw everything
that was happening here.

I just decided to take that
money, buy the plane ticket
and come out here.”
“Oh, Adam.”

“Oh, we got some food
out there for you.
You ready?”

“My mom asked me if I wanted
to go volunteer here in Europe.

She wanted me to be in Poland
to help the refugees.

And the next day, I was
thinking about it at work.

I was working at the
dollar store, you know?

And I just decided
that I’m going to do it.

I told her that I’m
going to Ukraine to help.

I didn’t really give her
specifics on fighting

because I didn’t want her
to worry and stuff like that.

But yeah, she wasn’t too happy
when I told her I was even

going to Ukraine,
let alone Kyiv,
let alone fight in Kyiv.”

The volunteers
packed their bags

and headed east
toward the fighting

with no weapons
and no clear plan.

“I don’t think that only
foreigners can save us,
definitely not.

But the feeling of solidarity
and to unite in,

how to say,
links between people —

they feel that they
have support of globe.
It’s incredible, really.”

For the foreign fighters who
went to the training center,
the war soon found them.

After the bombing,
Pedro, Ricardo and Jasper
evacuated to Poland,

where they’re now deciding
what to do next.

“I feel like I
deserted my pride.

But sometimes it’s better
to live to fight another day

than to die from bombs
for nothing.

Like, what can I do when
I’m dead? Nothing.”

Adam found his way to Kyiv
by himself and enlisted with

the international legion,
where he says he’ll be paid

the equivalent of
$3,000 a month.

“I want to be not necessarily
in the very, very front lines,

but I want to be out there
where the action is.

I came to defend Ukraine
with my hands.”

Viktor and Draven also
made it to Kyiv with Doc

and are trying to figure out
how they can help
with humanitarian aid.
“It’s empty.

Practically, it’s empty,
you see?”
